'''Hareth''' was the elder daughter of [[Halmir]], [[Chieftain of the Haladin|chieftain]] of the [[Haladin]], and sister of [[Haldir (Chieftain of the Haladin)|Haldir]], [[Hundar]],<ref name="Haladin">{{WJ|West}}, ''(iii) The Haladin''', p. 237</ref> and [[Hiril]].<ref>{{WJ|Hurin}}, p. 270</ref>  

== History ==
In {{FA|436}}<ref name=guide>{{GA|161|note}}</ref> there was a great feast of the [[Edain]], when she and her brother married with two children of [[Hador]] of the [[House of Marach]]; whereas Hareth married [[Galdor (Lord of Dor-lómin)|Galdor]], [[Lord of Dor-lómin]], her brother married Galdor's sister, [[Glóredhel]].<ref>{{S|Fingolfin}}</ref>

Hareth bore him two sons, [[Húrin]] and [[Huor]].<ref name="Haladin"/>

Disasters such as the [[Nirnaeth Arnoediad]], the death of childless [[Brandir the Lame]] by Hareth's grandson [[Túrin]],<ref>{{S|Turin}}</ref> and the coming of her son Húrin to [[Brethil]], causing the ruin of [[Obel Halad]],<ref>{{WJ|Hurin}}, pp. 291-4</ref> resulted to the dwindling and decline of Hareth's people.<ref>{{PM|Ros}}, Note 17</ref> Fortunately, her union with the [[House of Hador]], kept the lineage of her House alive through her grandson, [[Tuor]].

== Etymology ==
''Hareth'' also appears in ''[[Haudh-en-Arwen#Names|Tûr Haretha]]'', the "Ladybarrow", so the name probably means "Lady" in the [[Halethian|Haladin tongue]].<ref>{{S|West}}</ref>

[[Robert Foster]] also suggests that ''Hareth'' means "Lady",<ref name=guide/> however the entry erroneously labels the name as [[Quenya]].

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
Halmir's second daughter, Hiril, was a later addition to the family tree of the House of Haleth. Before she was introduced Hareth's name was ''Hiriel''.<ref>{{WJ|Hurin}}, footnote, p. 269</ref>
